meeting_annotations.speaker: Paola Boggiatto, ARS-USDA
meeting_annotations.transcript: You know, I think I think maybe one of the big messages that I'm getting out of this conference and and having the opportunity to talk to you guys, you know, I think we all use the terminology of precision precision surveillance as a catch all umbrella, but I think it's going to take different shapes and different forms depending on what you're trying to surveil, right? So, um, I think for a vector born disease or vector born diseases, that's going to be much, much different than for something like I'm trying to do or a disease that's not um, you know, I don't have a vector. I I need to worry about the animal. Is it going to be a wildlife versus a domestic animal, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Paola Boggiatto, ARS-USDA
meeting_annotations.transcript: So it almost seems like the technology platforms are out there. Um, we just need to figure out, you know, what's our target? Are we trying to get a big picture that then we can say, okay, we know that there is a virus. Uh now let's go back to that side and figure out which virus, right? So, um, I I think Crystal was pointing to to that, right? That you can say, well, here we can tell you that there is some virus, but maybe go back later and so the precision is not necessarily telling you what the pathogen is, but maybe it's telling you that there is a viral infection or a bacterial infection or a parasitic infection. So it almost seems like um maybe the biggest challenge is that we need to think more closely in terms of what we are trying to what we're trying to accomplish and communicate that to the engineers, right? Because the engineers can say, oh yeah, yeah, we can we can develop that. We can we can do a color change, we can do um, we can we can develop a detection method, but then how do we use that information, right? How does that inform us? Is that really surveillance or is that just like, oh, we we have a color change, right? So, so maybe maybe that's part of of the problem is really identifying what true precision is for us and what does that precision mean in terms of decision making, policy making or going back and doing further, you know, further testing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Crystal Hepp - Northern Arizona University
meeting_annotations.transcript: Bethany, would you mind sharing your sharing the screen maybe and um for would that help if we were to look at it and help you go through it?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bethany McGregor-USDA: ARS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so I think another challenge that we talked about at at kind of the top of the hour, you know, was personnel and experience because, you know, having something super complex out there that nobody but like three people are capable of actually working isn't very useful in the end, you know, having something that's simple enough that almost anybody can collect those data.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bethany McGregor-USDA: ARS
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think is going to be key towards having a really good surveillance program. I mean, right now for for mosquito born disease surveillance, a lot of what we're doing is catching a bunch of mosquitoes and then you need somebody who is a dedicated taxonomist who can go through and ID all these species and you need somebody who can do all the, you know, molecular work to identify those viruses and it it gets complicated.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bethany McGregor-USDA: ARS
meeting_annotations.transcript: So if we can come up with precision surveillance tools that are simple to use, straightforward and don't require, you know, advanced knowledge, I think that'll that'll change the game quite a bit. meeting_annotations.speaker: A. Ali Yanik, PHD (UC, Santa Cruz)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right. Do you use robotic systems in these days?

meeting_annotations.speaker: A. Ali Yanik, PHD (UC, Santa Cruz)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like when the sample is is ready to analyze.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bethany McGregor-USDA: ARS
meeting_annotations.transcript: So there are a few separate systems right now and I don't know of any that have brought everything together. There are several groups who are making automated mosquito traps that as they're collecting mosquitoes, they can use the wing beat frequency. So every mosquito flaps its wings in a slightly different way and they can use that information to ID the mosquitoes that are entering the traps. Um, but I don't know of any and then like I said, there are traps where they're live collecting these mosquitoes, having them feed on those honey cards and then um they take that back to the lab to detect.
